elements.content: Two novel three-dimensional lanthanide-organic frameworks, [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) (pydc2– is the deprotonated residue of 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid - 2,5-H2pydc), were prepared by hydrothermal synthesis. Compound 1 consists of an unique one-dimensional (1D) cationic [Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n 10n+ inorganic chain embedded into an organic matrix formed by the linker. Individual chains are disposed in the ab plane of the unit cell in a brick-wall fashion and result from the coalescence of cubane-type clusters of Er3+. Compound 2 comprises densely packed cationic [Er3(OH)6Cl] n 2n+ inorganic layers, constructed by the lateral coalescence of 1D chains identical to those found in 1. These layers are pillared by the organic linkers along the [001] direction of the unit cell yielding the crystal structure of 2. Considering the metallic tetramers and the ligands as framework nodes, compounds 1 and 2 are 7- and 2-nodal networks, respectively. While the former is unprecedented among metal–organic framework (MOF) structures, the latter is reminiscent of the known tcj/hc topological type. The crystal structures and properties of the two compounds have been investigated by (single-crystal and powder) X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy (SEM and EDX), vibrational spectroscopy, CHN elemental analyses, and thermogravimetry. The magnetic properties of 1 also have been investigated.

elements.content: Research on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) remains one of the most active areas in chemistry and materials science. This occurs because of their highly attractive and topologically diverse architectures. In theory, the number of possible frameworks is infinite because under the appropriate synthesis conditions metal centers and suitable organic molecules with donor groups may link to form crystalline networks, often exhibiting promising properties. In contrast to zeolites and related materials, porous MOFs have the great advantage of allowing the design of framework architectures and the functionalization of the inner pores, either by a judicious choice of the synthesis conditions or via postsynthetic modification. MOFs have been exploited in gas separations and storage, drug delivery, and other biomedical applications for their luminescence properties, catalytic activity, chirality, host–guest exchange, conductivity and magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Research on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) remains one of the most active areas in chemistry and materials science. This occurs because of their highly attractive and topologically diverse architectures. In theory, the number of possible frameworks is infinite because under the appropriate synthesis conditions metal centers and suitable organic molecules with donor groups may link to form crystalline networks, often exhibiting promising properties. In contrast to zeolites and related materials, porous MOFs have the great advantage of allowing the design of framework architectures and the functionalization of the inner pores, either by a judicious choice of the synthesis conditions or via postsynthetic modification. MOFs have been exploited in gas separations and storage, drug delivery, and other biomedical applications for their luminescence properties, catalytic activity, chirality, host-guest exchange, conductivity and magnetic properties.

elements.content: The use of lanthanides as metal centers in MOFs (lanthanide-organic frameworks, LnOFs) has become very popular in recent years. The reason for such concerns the propensity of these cations to high and variable coordination numbers and geometries, leading to complex network topologies and interesting properties, including magnetism and photoluminescence. H2pydc is a pyridine derivative (closely related to terephtalic acid, the iconic ligand of MOFs reported by Yaghi and Férey) and a multicarboxylic acid molecule. H2pydc readily coordinates lanthanide cations, behaving as a multiple (O, N) donor, effectively linking metal centers to generate MOF structures. Examples of the latter include microporous [Ce2(pydc)2(Hpydc)(H2O)2]Cl­·(9+y)H2O, which was quickly prepared using microwave irradiation, and the modular frameworks based on di-, tetra-, and hexameric hydroxoclusters of lanthanides, exhibiting a remarkable structural diversity.

The reason for such concerns the propensity of these cations to high and variable coordination numbers and geometries, leading to complex network topologies and interesting properties, including magnetism and photoluminescence. H2pydc is a pyridine derivative (closely related to terephtalic acid, the iconic ligand of MOFs reported by Yaghi and Férey) and a multicarboxylic acid molecule. H2pydc readily coordinates lanthanide cations, behaving as a multiple (O, N) donor, effectively linking metal centers to generate MOF structures. Examples of the latter include microporous [Ce2(pydc)2(Hpydc)(H2O)2]Cl⋅(9+y)H2O, which was quickly prepared using microwave irradiation, and the modular frameworks based on di-, tetra-, and hexameric hydroxoclusters of lanthanides, exhibiting a remarkable structural diversity.

elements.content: As a continuation of our research efforts toward the synthesis and structural characterization of novel Ln3+-MOFs, we wish to report two novel three-dimensional (3D) modular framework materials resulting from the self-assembly of Er3+ and 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2pydc) and based on tetrameric units: [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2). A search in the literature and in the Cambridge Structural Database yields a large number of structures containing tetrameric [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubane-type or related clusters. However, compounds 1 and 2 are unique and present some uncommon features: while the finite coalescence of the tetrameric units via a Ln3+ center has been reported for a number of cyclic discrete complexes and for the dicubane [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ moiety, the infinite coalescence into a one-dimensional (1D) inorganic chain embedded into an organic matrix, as observed in 1, is unprecedented. Compound 2 constitutes an example of the next self-assembly step as it is composed of densely packed inorganic layers formed by the parallel coalescence of similar cationic chains as those of 1. As in LDH-type materials, the crystal structure of compound 2 is formed by the pillaring of these layers by the organic ligands.

A search in the literature and in the Cambridge Structural Database yields a large number of structures containing tetrameric [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ cubane-type or related clusters. However, compounds 1 and 2 are unique and present some uncommon features: while the finite coalescence of the tetrameric units via a Ln3+ center has been reported for a number of cyclic discrete complexes and for the dicubane [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ moiety, the infinite coalescence into a one-dimensional (1D) inorganic chain embedded into an organic matrix, as observed in 1, is unprecedented. Compound 2 constitutes an example of the next self-assembly step as it is composed of densely packed inorganic layers formed by the parallel coalescence of similar cationic chains as those of 1. As in LDH-type materials, the crystal structure of compound 2 is formed by the pillaring of these layers by the organic ligands.

elements.content: All chemicals were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification: 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-H2pydc, C7H5NO4, purum ≥ 98%, Fluka), erbium(III) chloride hydrate (ErCl3·6H2O, ≥ 99,9%, Aldrich), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH pellets, Panreac).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents

All chemicals were readily available from commercial sources and were used as received without further purification: 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-H2pydc, C7H5NO4, purum ≥ 98%, Fluka), erbium(III) chloride hydrate (ErCl3⋅6H2O, ≥ 99,9%, Aldrich), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH pellets, Panreac).

elements.content: A suspension containing 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-H2pydc), erbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (ErCl3·6H2O), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) in distilled water was magnetically stirred thoroughly for 1 h at ambient temperature. The resulting homogeneous suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined Parr Instruments autoclave and placed inside a preheated oven. After the reaction, the vessel was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature before opening. Materials were recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with copious amounts of distilled water, and air-dried.
elements.clean_text:
Typical Hydrothermal Synthesis of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2)

General Procedure

A suspension containing 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (2,5-H2pydc), erbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (ErCl3⋅6H2O), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) in distilled water was magnetically stirred thoroughly for 1 h at ambient temperature. The resulting homogeneous suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined Parr Instruments autoclave and placed inside a preheated oven. After the reaction, the vessel was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature before opening. Materials were recovered by vacuum filtration, washed with copious amounts of distilled water, and air-dried.

Results and Discussion

Hydrothermal Synthesis

[Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) were isolated as phase-pure materials using typical hydrothermal synthesis during 3 days. Experimental details were fine-tuned to derive the optimal conditions (see details in the ). The study of the influence of the reaction parameters (data not shown) over the products revealed the following:

elements.content: (i) Low pH (2 or 3) of the initial reaction mixture promotes the formation of the tetragonal phase [Er2(pydc)3(H2O)2] previously reported by Huang et al. Compounds 1 and 2 are preferentially isolated in a narrow pH range, between 6 and 7. Under basic conditions the obtained materials are poorly crystalline.

elements.content:
(ii) A minimum temperature of 145 °C is necessary to isolate crystalline 1 and 2.

(iii) Compound 1 is preferentially isolated for diluted reaction mixtures (e.g., a ligand/metal/NaOH/H2O molar ratio of 1: 1: 2.5: 800). It is, however, important to emphasize that crystallinity also decreases significantly for very diluted systems (up to the tested 1: 1: 2.5: 1600 conditions). This parameter is also a detrimental factor to isolate highly crystalline compound 1;

(iv) Increasing the concentration of the metal in the initial reaction mixture (e.g., reaction mixtures with 1: 2: 2.5: 800 or 1: 1: 2.5: 400 molar ratios) promotes the isolation of pure compound 2.

Phase purity and homogeneity of the bulk materials isolated for each optimal synthetic condition were inspected using a combination of powder X-ray diffraction and electron microscopy studies (Figure and Figure S1 in ), alongside CHN elemental analysis and vibrational spectroscopy studies.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and SEM images of bulk materials prepared using hydrothermal reactions at 170 °C during 3 days. For identical molar ratio and pH conditions, phase-pure [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1), as needle-like crystals, is isolated using diluted reaction mixtures (as a ligand:metal:NaOH:H2O molar ratio of about 1: 1: 2.5: 800), whereas phase-pure [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) (plate-like crystals) is isolated when increasing the concentration of the metal in the initial reactive mixture (up to 4-fold).

elements.content: Crystals of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) were isolated as long needles with a rather uniform size distribution (Figure ). Compound [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) is usually isolated as plate-like crystals (Figure ). In this case, there is a tendency to occur aggregation of crystallites, leading to clusters with irregular dimensions and shapes.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Morphology

Crystals of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) were isolated as long needles with a rather uniform size distribution (Figure ). Compound [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) is usually isolated as plate-like crystals (Figure ). In this case, there is a tendency to occur aggregation of crystallites, leading to clusters with irregular dimensions and shapes.

elements.content: Two novel 3D LnOF materials were isolated from hydrothermal synthesis and formulated as [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) on the basis of single-crystal diffraction studies and CHN elemental analyses (Table ). In a previous study, we reported a series of 3D modular frameworks based on distinct Ln3+ clusters: dimers in (CH3)2NH2[Ln(pydc)2]­·1/2H2O (with Ln3+ = Eu3+ and Er3+), tetramers in [Er4(OH)4(pydc)4­(H2O)3]·H2O and hexamers in [Pr3.25O(OH)3(pydc)3]. We now describe materials with increased dimensionality of the inorganic clusters, viz., chains (1) and layers (2). Compounds 1 and 2 are true hybrid materials because they exhibit a clear separation between the organic matrix (pydc2– ligands) and inorganic {[Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n 10n+ chains in 1 and [Er3(OH)6Cl]2+ layers in 2}.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description

Two novel 3D LnOF materials were isolated from hydrothermal synthesis and formulated as [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) on the basis of single-crystal diffraction studies and CHN elemental analyses (Table ). In a previous study, we reported a series of 3D modular frameworks based on distinct Ln3+ clusters: dimers in (CH3)2NH2[Ln(pydc)2]⋅1/2H2O (with Ln3+ = Eu3+ and Er3+), tetramers in [Er4(OH)4(pydc)4(H2O)3]⋅H2O and hexamers in [Pr3.25O(OH)3(pydc)3]. We now describe materials with increased dimensionality of the inorganic clusters, viz., chains (1) and layers (2). Compounds 1 and 2 are true hybrid materials because they exhibit a clear separation between the organic matrix (pydc2- ligands) and inorganic {[Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n  10n+ chains in 1 and [Er3(OH)6Cl]2+ layers in 2}.

Compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic P21/c space group (Table ), with the asymmetric unit (asu) comprising six crystallographically independent Er3+ centers, eight μ3-bridging OH hydroxyl groups, five pydc2– organic linkers, three coordinated and two and a half uncoordinated water molecules (). The Er2 and Er6 centers are nine-coordinated ({ErO9} and {ErO8N}, respectively) with the coordination spheres resembling distorted monocapped square antiprisms (), while the remaining Er3+ centers are eight-coordinated ({ErO8} and {ErO7N} for Er1 and Er3–Er5, respectively) with overall coordination geometries resembling distorted dodecahedra (): Er1 is coordinated to two O-atoms of two pydc2– residues and six hydroxyl groups (Figure b); Er2 is coordinated to one pydc2‑ ligand in a syn,syn-unidentate coordination fashion, six hydroxyl groups and one water molecule (Figure c); Er3 and Er5 show similar overall coordination environments, being coordinated by four O-atoms from four pydc2– residues, one N-atom of one of these ligands and three hydroxyl groups (Figure d,f); Er4 coordinates to three O-atoms from three distinct pydc2– ligands, one N-atom, three hydroxyl groups and one water molecule (Figure e); finally, the coordination environment of Er6 is composed of three O- and one N-atom from three distinct pydc2– ligands, three hydroxyl groups and two water molecules (Figure g; tabulated bond lengths and angles associated with all Er3+ coordination environments are provided in Tables S1–S3 in the ).

elements.content: Compound 1 is based on a heptanuclear cluster composed of six crystallographic independent Er3+ centers (Er1, Er2, Er3, Er4, Er5, and Er6), with the seventh being a symmetry-generated Er2i [symmetry transformation: (i) x, 1/2 – y, 1/2 + z]. This high nuclearity unit results from the coalescence of two tetranuclear clusters with a distorted cubane-like [Er4(μ3-OH)4]8+ arrangement, i.e., four Er3+ centers are bonded together by four hydroxyl groups placed at opposite vertices of the cuboidal arrangement  O5, O6, O7, O8 and O1, O2, O3, O4 (Figure a and Scheme S1 in ). While one cubane-like unit is formed by Er1, Er2, Er3, and Er4 (cub_1), the other is instead build up by Er1, Er5, Er6, and Er2i (cub_2). In the cubane-like tetranuclear clusters the four Er3+ metallic centers are located at the four apexes of slightly distorted tetrahedra with the intermetallic Er···Er distances ranging from 3.4510(6) to 3.8832(7) Å for cub_1, and from 3.4194(7) to 3.8338(7) Å for cub_2 (Scheme S1 in summarizes all individual Er···Er distances). Each triangular face of the Er3+ tetrahedra is capped by one of the μ3-OH groups [Er-OH distances ranging between 2.283(6) and 2.529(7) Å for cub_1, and from 2.267(6) to 2.394(6) Å in cub_2; see Table S1 in for individual distances].

This high nuclearity unit results from the coalescence of two tetranuclear clusters with a distorted cubane-like [Er4(μ3-OH)4]8+ arrangement, i.e., four Er3+ centers are bonded together by four hydroxyl groups placed at opposite vertices of the cuboidal arrangement  O5, O6, O7, O8 and O1, O2, O3, O4 (Figure a and Scheme S1 in ). While one cubane-like unit is formed by Er1, Er2, Er3, and Er4 (cub_1), the other is instead build up by Er1, Er5, Er6, and Er2i (cub_2). In the cubane-like tetranuclear clusters the four Er3+ metallic centers are located at the four apexes of slightly distorted tetrahedra with the intermetallic Er⋅⋅⋅Er distances ranging from 3.4510(6) to 3.8832(7) Å for cub_1, and from 3.4194(7) to 3.8338(7) Å for cub_2 (Scheme S1 in  summarizes all individual Er⋅⋅⋅Er distances). Each triangular face of the Er3+ tetrahedra is capped by one of the μ3-OH groups [Er-OH distances ranging between 2.283(6) and 2.529(7) Å for cub_1, and from 2.267(6) to 2.394(6) Å in cub_2; see Table S1 in  for individual distances].

elements.content: The interconnectivity of individual heptanuclear clusters along the [001] direction of the unit cell is ensured by the Er2 metallic centers with a typical zigzag fashion (Figure a), leading to the formation of pure cationic lanthanide hydroxide inorganic chains. These cationic [Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n 10n+ chains are completely surrounded by the pydc2– ligands (organic matrix), thus originating a true organic–organic hybrid material (Figure a,b). As mentioned previously, the structure of 1 is based on five crystallographic independent anionic pydc2– residues: three ligands coordinate to only three Er3+ centers with the connectivities depicted in Scheme A (ligand containing the N1 atom) and 1C (those containing the N3 and N4 atoms); the remaining linkers (those having N2 and N5) establish bridges between four Er3+ centers according the coordination modes depicted in Scheme B. As a consequence of this multitude of coordination modes the cationic inorganic chains, disposed in a typical brick-wall-like arrangement, are interconnected in the ab plane of the unit cell by the pydc2– ligands. This leads to the formation of the crystal structure of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3] (Figure ).

elements.content: The structural robustness of the framework is considerably strengthened by the presence of a O–H···O and O–H···N hydrogen bonding network interconnecting coordinated water molecules (O1W, O10W, and O20W/O21W), hydroxyl groups (O1 and O2), oxygen atoms of adjacent carboxylate oxygen atoms, and the N5 atom of coordinated ligands (intraframework hydrogen bonds; see Table for further details on the geometrical features of these supramolecular interactions). Additionally, the two and a half lattice water molecules (disordered over five distinct crystallographic positions: O11W, O12W, O13W, O14W, and O15W) are also engaged in numerous intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions with the neutral framework (not shown).

Additionally, the two and a half lattice water molecules (disordered over five distinct crystallographic positions: O11W, O12W, O13W, O14W, and O15W) are also engaged in numerous intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions with the neutral framework (not shown).

Compound 2, [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl], crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbca space group with the asu unit being composed of only three crystallographically independent lanthanide Er3+ centers interconnected by six bridging hydroxyl groups, one pydc2– ligand and a coordinated chloride anion (Table ; ). The three crystallographically independent lanthanide centers have distinct coordination environments: Er1 is coordinated by three crystallographic independent O-atoms of μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups, four O-atoms and one N-atom of three symmetry-equivalent organic ligands and a chlorido anion, in a {ErClNO7} eight-coordination environment whose geometry resembles a distorted dodechaedron (Figure a and Figure S5a in ); Er2 is coordinated to five oxygen atoms of μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups (O1, O2, O4, O5, and O5iv), one O-atom of the bridging μ2-O hydroxyl group (O6) and one O-atom of the organic linker (O10i). This seven-coordination environment {ErClNO7} has a geometry which resembles a distorted capped trigonal prism (Figure b and Figure S5b in ); Er3 is eight-coordinated with an overall distorted dodecahedral geometry, being formed exclusively by O-atoms of bridging hydroxyl groups (O1, O2, O3, O5vi, O2vii, O3vii, and O4vii are μ3-O atoms, while O6vi is a μ2-O atom (Figure c and Figure S5c in ). Detailed and systematized information related to the individual bond lengths and angles of the three Er3+ coordination centers is given in Tables S4 and S5 (in ), respectively.

The three crystallographically independent lanthanide centers have distinct coordination environments: Er1 is coordinated by three crystallographic independent O-atoms of μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups, four O-atoms and one N-atom of three symmetry-equivalent organic ligands and a chlorido anion, in a {ErClNO7} eight-coordination environment whose geometry resembles a distorted dodechaedron (Figure a and Figure S5a in ); Er2 is coordinated to five oxygen atoms of μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups (O1, O2, O4, O5, and O5iv), one O-atom of the bridging μ2-O hydroxyl group (O6) and one O-atom of the organic linker (O10i). This seven-coordination environment {ErClNO7} has a geometry which resembles a distorted capped trigonal prism (Figure b and Figure S5b in ); Er3 is eight-coordinated with an overall distorted dodecahedral geometry, being formed exclusively by O-atoms of bridging hydroxyl groups (O1, O2, O3, O5vi, O2vii, O3vii, and O4vii are μ3-O atoms, while O6vi is a μ2-O atom (Figure c and Figure S5c in ). Detailed and systematized information related to the individual bond lengths and angles of the three Er3+ coordination centers is given in Tables S4 and S5 (in ), respectively.

elements.content: As compound 1, Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] is also a true hybrid LnOF because of the markedly distinct location of the organic (pydc2– ligand) and the inorganic (layer) components in the crystal structure. The interconnectivity of Er3+ metallic centers ensured exclusively by the μ2- and μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups leads to the formation of two-dimensional (2D) inorganic cationic networks {i.e., layers; [Er3(OH)6Cl] n 2n+} extended in the ab plane of the unit cell (Figure a). The structural robustness of this cationic layer is reinforced by the various O–H···Cl and O–H···O hydrogen bonds involving the bridging hydroxyl groups (O1, O2, O3 and O5) and the Cl– anion coordinated to Er1: O1–H1···Cl1x, O2–H2···Cl1vii, O5–H5···Cl1iv, and O3–H3···O6iii (intralayer hydrogen bonds represented as dashed lines in Figure S6 in ; Table contains information on geometrical details of these interactions). The crystallographically independent pydc2– organic ligand connects four Er3+ centers (three symmetry-related Er1 and one Er2 cation) through the coordination mode depicted in Scheme D. This ligand is responsible for pillaring adjacent inorganic layers and leading to the densely packed architecture of the LnOF (Figure b). The interaction between the inorganic and organic moieties is further strengthened by O–H···O hydrogen bonds involving hydroxyl groups (O4 and O6) and the carboxylate O-atoms of the pydc2– ligand (O7 and O19): O6–H6···O7vii and O4–H4···O10xi (Table ).

In the previously reported [Er4(OH)4(pydc)4(H2O)3]·H2O framework, the tetrameric building unit appears isolated in the crystal structure, with intertetramer connections being solely ensured by the chelating and/or bridging organic residues. The slight modification of the experimental conditions (see dedicated ) led to the isolation of two novel phases based on similar building units: on the one hand, in [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]·2.5H2O (1), tetramers are fused into 1D chains by corner-sharing of adjacent tetrameters (see Figure a); on the other, the previously described inorganic layers observed in [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) are simply obtained by the lateral coalescence of related 1D chains through μ2- and μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups (Figure b). This self-assembly is evident when taking into consideration the internodal distances: while along the chains distances are found in the narrow range of ca. 4.22–4.29 Å, the “gluing” hydroxyl bridges in 2 impose much longer distances (around ca. 7.02 Å  see Figure b). This step-by-step rationalization of the formation of 1 and 2 is also clearly demonstrated by the empirical formulas of the compounds: the coalescence of tetramers is accompanied by a decrease in the number of coordinating organic ligands, and the concomitant increase in the number of bridging hydroxyl groups.

Structure Relationships Based on the Tetramer Building Unit

In the previously reported [Er4(OH)4(pydc)4(H2O)3]⋅H2O framework, the tetrameric building unit appears isolated in the crystal structure, with intertetramer connections being solely ensured by the chelating and/or bridging organic residues. The slight modification of the experimental conditions (see dedicated ) led to the isolation of two novel phases based on similar building units: on the one hand, in [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1), tetramers are fused into 1D chains by corner-sharing of adjacent tetrameters (see Figure a); on the other, the previously described inorganic layers observed in [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) are simply obtained by the lateral coalescence of related 1D chains through μ2- and μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups (Figure b). This self-assembly is evident when taking into consideration the internodal distances: while along the chains distances are found in the narrow range of ca. 4.22-4.29 Å, the "gluing" hydroxyl bridges in 2 impose much longer distances (around ca. 7.02 Å  see Figure b). This step-by-step rationalization of the formation of 1 and 2 is also clearly demonstrated by the empirical formulas of the compounds: the coalescence of tetramers is accompanied by a decrease in the number of coordinating organic ligands, and the concomitant increase in the number of bridging hydroxyl groups.

The internodal distances along the inorganic chains and between adjacent ones (in 2) are also depicted.

elements.content: The modular structural features of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) are much better understood when the structures are described using a typical topological approach: i.e., frameworks are mathematically reduced into central nodes and connecting rods (acting as intermetallic bridges). However, due to the high complexity of the structures herein reported, the selection of nodes and rods needs to be careful and structurally meaningful. Alexandrov et al. suggested that any moiety (ligand or atoms) connecting more than two metallic centers (μ n ) should be considered as a network node. Taking for instance 1 this would mean, however, that all ligands, bridging hydroxyls and metallic centers would be nodes of the network itself, yielding a high-order 19-connected. This is, in fact, meaningless in the overall framework construction rationale (see above). In our previous report of modular MOFs based on dimeric, tetrameric and hexameric units we considered instead the centers of gravity of each unit as the nodes, ultimately reducing the frameworks to simple uninodal nets related to known materials. We believe that the same approach should be considered for 1 and 2. In addition, as described in the previous subsection, these tetrameric units coalesce to form a one-dimensional chain isolated in 1 and also composing the densely packed layer of 2. These tetramer-to-tetramer connections via a common vertex of the tetrameter should also be considered as a internodal connection as they are highly structurally significant. Based on this, the frameworks of 1 and 2 have been mathematically reduced to nodes and rods in the following manner:

Topological Studies

The modular structural features of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) are much better understood when the structures are described using a typical topological approach: i.e., frameworks are mathematically reduced into central nodes and connecting rods (acting as intermetallic bridges). However, due to the high complexity of the structures herein reported, the selection of nodes and rods needs to be careful and structurally meaningful. Alexandrov et al. suggested that any moiety (ligand or atoms) connecting more than two metallic centers (μ n ) should be considered as a network node. Taking for instance 1 this would mean, however, that all ligands, bridging hydroxyls and metallic centers would be nodes of the network itself, yielding a high-order 19-connected. This is, in fact, meaningless in the overall framework construction rationale (see above). In our previous report of modular MOFs based on dimeric, tetrameric and hexameric units we considered instead the centers of gravity of each unit as the nodes, ultimately reducing the frameworks to simple uninodal nets related to known materials. We believe that the same approach should be considered for 1 and 2. In addition, as described in the previous subsection, these tetrameric units coalesce to form a one-dimensional chain isolated in 1 and also composing the densely packed layer of 2. These tetramer-to-tetramer connections via a common vertex of the tetrameter should also be considered as a internodal connection as they are highly structurally significant. Based on this, the frameworks of 1 and 2 have been mathematically reduced to nodes and rods in the following manner:

elements.content:
(i) Nodes: centers of gravity of each crystallographically independent Er3+ tetramer and pydc2– anionic ligands

(ii) Bridges: internodal connections via the organic ligands (only connections through the carboxylate ligands were considered) and along the tetrameric-based chains with all topological studies being performed using the software package TOPOS.

elements.content: Compound 1 is a much more simplified 7-nodal network where each center of gravity of Er3+ tetramer is a 10-connected node and the five crystallographically independent pydc2‑ ligands range from 2-connected to 4-connected nodes (see Figure S7 in for a representation of each nodal connectivity). The overall Schäfli symbol of this network is, thus, {3·4·5}{3·42}{32·4·52·6}­{32·4·53}{36·411·58·616·74}­{36·49·55·613·710·82}{4} (Figure - top). Searches in the Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) and in EPINET reveal that this nodal connectivity is, to the best of our knowledge, unprecedented among MOF structures. We note that the high complexity of this network (and of its topological relationships) is closely related with the overall low symmetry of the crystalline structure in conjunction with the large asymmetric unit for the compound. This does not occur for 2: using the same rationale, this framework is a simple binodal network in which the Er3+ tetrameter is a 5-connected node and the pydc2– ligand a 3-connected node (see Figure S8 in for a representation of each nodal connectivity). The overall Schäfli symbol reflects this simplicity, {4·6·8}{4·64·85}, also showing that the framework is of known tcj/hc topological type (Figure - bottom).

elements.content:
The thermal stability of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) was investigated from the ambient temperature to ca. 700 °C (Figure S9 in the ).

The thermal decomposition of 1 occurs in three main stages with the structure remaining approximately unchanged up to ca. 400 °C. Given that the first two losses overlap, they have been considered together as a unique loss in the range ca. 21–390 °C. Overall, 1 loses in this range approximately 6.1% of the total weight, which agrees well with the release of seven water molecules per formula unit (calculated value of 6.2%). Noteworthy, the observed value of 7 water moieties is higher than the 5.5 expected (based on the empirical formula) which may be attributed to either unaccounted water molecules inside the channels of the framework or adsorbed molecules on the surface of the crystallites. Above ca. 425 °C the organic component starts to decompose, with the total observed weight loss being of about 33.5% (calculated 32.8% for the release of four ligand residues), leading to the formation of Er2O3 (calculated final residue of 56.3%; observed 59.8%). We note that the residue at 700 °C was isolated and identified from powder X-ray diffraction (PDF4+ database; Release 2012) as Er2O3 (ICDD 04-003-6254).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) was investigated from the ambient temperature to ca. 700 °C (Figure S9 in the ).

The thermal decomposition of 1 occurs in three main stages with the structure remaining approximately unchanged up to ca. 400 °C. Given that the first two losses overlap, they have been considered together as a unique loss in the range ca. 21-390 °C. Overall, 1 loses in this range approximately 6.1% of the total weight, which agrees well with the release of seven water molecules per formula unit (calculated value of 6.2%). Noteworthy, the observed value of 7 water moieties is higher than the 5.5 expected (based on the empirical formula) which may be attributed to either unaccounted water molecules inside the channels of the framework or adsorbed molecules on the surface of the crystallites. Above ca. 425 °C the organic component starts to decompose, with the total observed weight loss being of about 33.5% (calculated 32.8% for the release of four ligand residues), leading to the formation of Er2O3 (calculated final residue of 56.3%; observed 59.8%). We note that the residue at 700 °C was isolated and identified from powder X-ray diffraction (PDF4+ database; Release 2012) as Er2O3 (ICDD 04-003-6254).

elements.content: Compound 2 is thermally robust up to ca. 295 °C, after which two consecutive weight losses occur: the first, corresponding to ca. 3.7% up to ca. 407 °C is attributed to the liberation of 1.5 water residues per formula unit (calculated value of about 3.4%) probably arising from dehydration of the hydroxide layers; the second loss of about 27.8% is assigned to the simultaneous release/decomposition of the organic matrix, leading to the collapse of the network (calculated value 27.5%). The residue at 700 °C (ca. 68.9%) is again Er2O3 (ICDD 04-008-8240; calculated ca. 71.3%).

elements.content: Vibrational (FT-IR and FT-Raman) spectroscopy studies clearly support the main structural features unveiled by the X-ray diffraction analysis (see Figures S10 and S11 in ). The spectra for both compounds, [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2), markedly exhibit the same diagnostic bands reflecting: the presence of various hydroxyl groups and water molecules coordinated to the metallic centers; pydc2– residues exhibit a multitude of coordination modes to the Er3+ cations.
elements.clean_text:
Vibrational Spectroscopy

Vibrational (FT-IR and FT-Raman) spectroscopy studies clearly support the main structural features unveiled by the X-ray diffraction analysis (see Figures S10 and S11 in ). The spectra for both compounds, [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2), markedly exhibit the same diagnostic bands reflecting: the presence of various hydroxyl groups and water molecules coordinated to the metallic centers; pydc2- residues exhibit a multitude of coordination modes to the Er3+ cations.

elements.content: The spectral region between ca. 3600 and 3100 cm–1 exhibits for the two compounds a very broad band composed of several shoulders. As described in the crystallographic section, each compound contains several bridging hydroxyl groups involved in hydrogen bonding interactions. The stretching vibrational modes associated with these moieties, alongside with those of both coordinated and lattice water molecules in 1, appear in this region. The dispersion in wavenumbers is a direct consequence of the various chemical environments.

elements.content: Particularly diagnostic is the spectral range below ca. 1650 cm–1 for both compounds. Two groups of very strong bands appear in this region, being attributed to the stretching vibrational modes of coordinated carboxylate groups. While the bands at ca. 1619 and 1596 cm–1 for 1 and 2, respectively, are broad (still with various discernible shoulders) and assigned to Δ[υasym(−CO2– ), those below ca. 1417 cm–1 are more structured, clearly revealing the presence of the various coordination modes: for example, for 1 in this region there are least three bands (at ca. 1417, 1393, and 1360 cm–1; see Figure S10 in ), which correspond to average Δ[υasym(−CO2– ) - υsym(−CO2– )] values of ca. 202, 226, and 259 cm–1 in good agreement with the predominance of syn,syn-bridging, syn- and anti-unidentate coordination fashions for the pydc2– organic linkers (Schemes A–C). Notably, as clearly depicted in Figure S10 in , for 1 there is a shoulder at 1435 cm–1. The analogous band is absent in the FT-IR spectrum of 2. This observation agrees well with the existence of the syn,syn-chelating mode in 1 (Scheme A) which is not present for 2 (Scheme D).

elements.content: A number of medium-intensity, but sharp, bands in the 1100–500 cm–1 spectral region alongside with the weak band peaking about ca. 1480 cm–1 in both compounds are indicative of the presence of 2,5-disubstituted pyridine organic moieties.

elements.content: Magnetic properties are among those expected a priori to be of interest in the present compounds, because Er3+ ions possess ground states with nonzero magnetic moment and they are in close proximity in the compounds herein reported. In particular, 1 is composed of Er3+ clusters separated by organic molecules, which could lead to interesting single-molecule magnet behavior. In this view, the thermal dependence of the magnetic susceptibility χ of 1 was studied in detail. For this compound χ has a monotonic decrease with temperature, which can be qualitatively described as a Curie-like decrease, and no thermal irreversibility. In a closer look, a monotonic increase of the χT product with temperature toward the Er3+ free ion limit is observed (theoretical value: 11.48 cm3 K/molEr; experimental value: 11.8 cm3 K/molEr), corresponding to L = 6, S = 3/2 and J = 15/2).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Magnetic properties are among those expected a priori to be of interest in the present compounds, because Er3+ ions possess ground states with nonzero magnetic moment and they are in close proximity in the compounds herein reported. In particular, 1 is composed of Er3+ clusters separated by organic molecules, which could lead to interesting single-molecule magnet behavior. In this view, the thermal dependence of the magnetic susceptibility χ of 1 was studied in detail. For this compound χ has a monotonic decrease with temperature, which can be qualitatively described as a Curie-like decrease, and no thermal irreversibility. In a closer look, a monotonic increase of the χT product with temperature toward the Er3+ free ion limit is observed (theoretical value: 11.48 cm3 K/molEr; experimental value: 11.8 cm3 K/molEr), corresponding to L = 6, S = 3/2 and J = 15/2).

elements.content: The χT temperature dependence of 1 is characteristic of Ln3+ ions in the presence of a crystal field, similar to that previously found in Er2O3 and La2–x Er x O3 compounds (0.2 < x < 2), for instance. In crystal fields with symmetry lower than cubic, the ground term of Er3+4I15/2 splits into eight Kramer’s doublets and the magnetic susceptibility can be expressed as χ = N g j 2 μ B 2 k T ∑ i M i eff 2 exp ( − E i / k T ) ∑ i exp ( − E i / k T ) where E i is the energy gap between the ground and the ith crystal field level and M ieff denotes linear combinations of the free ion magnetic quantum numbers M J. In practice, it is a good approximation to consider M ieff ≈ M J (with M J = ± 1/2 ± 3/2 ± 5/2 ± 7/2 ± 9/2 ± 11/2 ± 13/2 ± 15/2). Under this approximation, the χT temperature dependence can be well described with E 8 = 54.3 K, E 7 = 9.7 K, E 6 = 1.2 K and the remaining terms E i = 0 (see Figure ). Therefore, within the studied temperature range (which is associated to a given energy range) the Er3+ ions behave as isolated ions and not as single-molecule magnets. This means that possible exchange coupling between Er3+ ions of the heptanuclear cluster of 1 has characteristic energies typically below those of the order of 4 K. This is in line with the behavior previously found for Er3+-formate frameworks, where single ion paramagnetic behavior was found below ca. 4 K.

elements.content: Two novel Ln3+-based MOFs containing residues of the organic linker 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid, [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2), have been prepared by hydrothermal synthesis and their crystal structures fully unveiled. Compounds are true hybrid materials entailing one- or two-dimensional inorganic aggregates separated by the organic matrix. Compound 1 contains cationic inorganic [Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n 10n+ chains parallel to the c axis of the unit cell. Individual chains, distributed in a brick-wall-like fashion in the ab plane, are pillared by the organic linkers, which establish effective interchain connections. A few years ago we have reported the presence of interrupted inorganic chains in the 3D MOF material [PrIII 2PrIV 1.25O(OH)3(pydc)3]. In 1 the lanthanide hydroxide chains are infinite in nature and uncommon. Compound 2 is based on densely packed cationic [Er3(OH)6Cl] n 2n+ layers on the ab plane of the unit cell, which are pillared by the organic linkers along the [001] direction. Inorganic chains of 1 constitute the core of the inorganic layers observed in compound 2: the lateral coalescence of the chains by way of μ2- and μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups promoted the condensation into inorganic layers. Both compounds are, nevertheless, based on relatively similar tetrameric Er3+ building units: even though the cores are identical, the connectivity through the lateral coalescence and also by way of the bridging organic ligands constitutes the base for the observed structural diversity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two novel Ln3+-based MOFs containing residues of the organic linker 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid, [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]⋅2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2), have been prepared by hydrothermal synthesis and their crystal structures fully unveiled. Compounds are true hybrid materials entailing one- or two-dimensional inorganic aggregates separated by the organic matrix. Compound 1 contains cationic inorganic [Er6(OH)8(H2O)3] n  10n+ chains parallel to the c axis of the unit cell. Individual chains, distributed in a brick-wall-like fashion in the ab plane, are pillared by the organic linkers, which establish effective interchain connections. A few years ago we have reported the presence of interrupted inorganic chains in the 3D MOF material [PrIII 2PrIV 1.25O(OH)3(pydc)3]. In 1 the lanthanide hydroxide chains are infinite in nature and uncommon. Compound 2 is based on densely packed cationic [Er3(OH)6Cl] n  2n+ layers on the ab plane of the unit cell, which are pillared by the organic linkers along the [001] direction. Inorganic chains of 1 constitute the core of the inorganic layers observed in compound 2: the lateral coalescence of the chains by way of μ2- and μ3-bridging hydroxyl groups promoted the condensation into inorganic layers. Both compounds are, nevertheless, based on relatively similar tetrameric Er3+ building units: even though the cores are identical, the connectivity through the lateral coalescence and also by way of the bridging organic ligands constitutes the base for the observed structural diversity.

elements.content: The structural robustness of both compounds was found to be increased by various supramolecular interactions, particularly O–H···O hydrogen bonds involving the hydroxyl groups and the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules and chloride anions. This feature is markedly visible in the thermal studies that show that the two materials are thermally robust to relatively high temperatures.
elements.clean_text: The structural robustness of both compounds was found to be increased by various supramolecular interactions, particularly O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds involving the hydroxyl groups and the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules and chloride anions. This feature is markedly visible in the thermal studies that show that the two materials are thermally robust to relatively high temperatures.

elements.content: Magnetic studies of compound 1 show that the χT temperature dependence is characteristic of paramagnetic lanthanide ions, within the studied temperature range. We are currently optimizing the synthesis conditions of these materials in order to engineer other lanthanide centers into these networks, in particular optically active lanthanides such as Eu3+ and Tb3+. Even though the close proximity between these metallic centers is not enough to promote magnetic interactions apparent above 4.2 K, the various possible energy-transfer pathways are expected to give rise to interesting photoluminescent properties.

Crystallographic information files (CIF) and additional crystallographic representations for compounds 1 and 2. Additional experimental details and structural characterization data: TGA, FT-IR, and FT-Raman. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) Data (Weight Losses in %) and Derivative Thermogravimetric Peaks (DTG; in Italics, within Brackets)

[Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]·2.5H2O (1): 21–390 °C −6.1% (48 and 336 °C); 425–700 °C −33.5% (522 °C).

[Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2): 295–407 °C −3.7% (376 °C); 415–700 °C −27.8% (462 °C).

Results and DiscussionHydrothermal Synthesis

[Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) were isolated as phase-pure materials using typical hydrothermal synthesis during 3 days. Experimental details were fine-tuned to derive the optimal conditions (see details in the ). The study of the influence of the reaction parameters (data not shown) over the products revealed the following:

Thermal Stability

The thermal stability of [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1) and [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) was investigated from the ambient temperature to ca. 700 °C (Figure S9 in the ).

The thermal decomposition of 1 occurs in three main stages with the structure remaining approximately unchanged up to ca. 400 °C. Given that the first two losses overlap, they have been considered together as a unique loss in the range ca. 21–390 °C. Overall, 1 loses in this range approximately 6.1% of the total weight, which agrees well with the release of seven water molecules per formula unit (calculated value of 6.2%). Noteworthy, the observed value of 7 water moieties is higher than the 5.5 expected (based on the empirical formula) which may be attributed to either unaccounted water molecules inside the channels of the framework or adsorbed molecules on the surface of the crystallites. Above ca. 425 °C the organic component starts to decompose, with the total observed weight loss being of about 33.5% (calculated 32.8% for the release of four ligand residues), leading to the formation of Er2O3 (calculated final residue of 56.3%; observed 59.8%). We note that the residue at 700 °C was isolated and identified from powder X-ray diffraction (PDF4+ database; Release 2012) as Er2O3 (ICDD 04-003-6254).

Compound 2 is thermally robust up to ca. 295 °C, after which two consecutive weight losses occur: the first, corresponding to ca. 3.7% up to ca. 407 °C is attributed to the liberation of 1.5 water residues per formula unit (calculated value of about 3.4%) probably arising from dehydration of the hydroxide layers; the second loss of about 27.8% is assigned to the simultaneous release/decomposition of the organic matrix, leading to the collapse of the network (calculated value 27.5%). The residue at 700 °C (ca. 68.9%) is again Er2O3 (ICDD 04-008-8240; calculated ca. 71.3%).

Magnetic Properties

Magnetic properties are among those expected a priori to be of interest in the present compounds, because Er3+ ions possess ground states with nonzero magnetic moment and they are in close proximity in the compounds herein reported. In particular, 1 is composed of Er3+ clusters separated by organic molecules, which could lead to interesting single-molecule magnet behavior. In this view, the thermal dependence of the magnetic susceptibility χ of 1 was studied in detail. For this compound χ has a monotonic decrease with temperature, which can be qualitatively described as a Curie-like decrease, and no thermal irreversibility. In a closer look, a monotonic increase of the χT product with temperature toward the Er3+ free ion limit is observed (theoretical value: 11.48 cm3 K/molEr; experimental value: 11.8 cm3 K/molEr), corresponding to L = 6, S = 3/2 and J = 15/2).

cln_elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and SEM images of bulk materials prepared using hydrothermal reactions at 170 °C during 3 days. For identical molar ratio and pH conditions, phase-pure [Er6(OH)8(pydc)5(H2O)3]­·2.5H2O (1), as needle-like crystals, is isolated using diluted reaction mixtures (as a ligand:metal:NaOH:H2O molar ratio of about 1: 1: 2.5: 800), whereas phase-pure [Er3(OH)6(pydc)Cl] (2) (plate-like crystals) is isolated when increasing the concentration of the metal in the initial reactive mixture (up to 4-fold).
